title: America's role in combating global poverty examined in new book
description: Aristotle famously wrote, "Poverty is the parent of revolution and crime."
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Consistent metabolism may prove costly for insects in saltier water
description: Increased salinity usually spells trouble for freshwater insects like mayflies. A new study from North Carolina State University finds that the lack of metabolic responses to salinity may explain why some freshwater insects often struggle in higher salinity, while other freshwater invertebrates (like mollusks and crustaceans) thrive. Salinity in this case refers to the concentrations of all the salts in an aquatic environment, not just sodium.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New study looks at attitudes towards political violence
description: A small segment of the U.S. population considers violence, including lethal violence, to be usually or always justified to advance political objectives. This is according to newly published research from the UC Davis Violence Prevention Research Program (VPRP).
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How to protect self-esteem when a career goal dies
description: Many people fail at achieving their early career dreams. But a new study suggests that those failures don't have to harm your self-esteem if you think about them in the right way.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: AI-driven earthquake forecasting shows promise in trials
description: A new attempt to predict earthquakes with the aid of artificial intelligence has raised hopes that the technology could one day be used to limit earthquakes' impact on lives and economies. Developed by researchers at The University of Texas at Austin, the AI algorithm correctly predicted 70% of earthquakes a week before they happened during a seven-month trial in China.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Salmon are spawning in Arctic rivers, researchers confirm
description: Researchers have confirmed that salmon are spawning in an Arctic Ocean watershed, suggesting that at least some salmon species could be expanding to new territory as climate change reshapes their habitat.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: 'Roving sentinels' discover new air pollution sources
description: In 2019, University of Utah atmospheric scientists, the Environmental Defense Fund and other partners added a new tool to their quiver of air quality monitors—two Google Street View cars, Salt Lake Valley's roving sentinels that would detect hyper-local air pollution hotspots.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study: Tipped restaurant workers in Chicago compensated at rates below minimum wage
description: A new study co-written by a team of University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign labor researchers assessing the state of food service and bar employment in the city of Chicago found that more than three-quarters of tipped workers surveyed were compensated at an hourly wage rate of less than the standard Chicago minimum wage but higher than the sub-minimum wage allowed for employees who rely on customer gratuity to supplement their paychecks.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Don't feel appreciated by your partner? Relationship interventions can help
description: When we're married or in a long-term romantic relationship, we may eventually come to take each other for granted and forget to show appreciation. A new study from the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign finds that it doesn't have to stay this way.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Research offers insight into AI protections for workers
description: As artificial intelligence takes on a larger role in monitoring employees and automating management decisions, Virginia Doellgast offers examples from Germany and Norway showing how worker representatives have been able to mobilize collective voice to protect worker privacy.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Hubble captures starry Cetus constellation galaxy
description: New and old stars alike twinkle in the dusty spiral arms of NGC 1087. Located 80 million light-years away in the constellation Cetus, NGC 1087 is a barred spiral galaxy. It has a diameter of 87,000 light-years and a very small nucleus, or center.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Saudi firm that grows hay in California and Arizona to lose farm leases over water issue
description: A Saudi dairy company that grows hay in Southern California and Arizona for export to the Middle East is set to lose several leases that allow it to pump unlimited water from government-owned farmlands.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Small-scale magnetism leads to large-scale solar atmosphere
description: Thanks to close-up images of the sun obtained during Solar Orbiter's perihelion passage of October 2022, solar physicists have seen how fleeting magnetic fields at the solar surface build up into the solar atmosphere.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Meet the next alien invaders to threaten nature and economies in Scotland
description: Raccoons, muntjac deer, plants that cause flooding, and mussels that clog up water pipes are among the new problem species that are likely to arrive in Scotland over the next decade and pose a serious threat to nature or people.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Secondary education needs to empower students to respond to climate emergency, says UK report
description: The UK government needs to do more to equip schools with the materials and resources to teach young people about climate change and their role in responding to it by refocusing the school curriculum, according to the authors of new research.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Andalusian families do not have the same bilingual education opportunities, says study
description: According to a study, factors such as their place of residence, the economic level of their neighborhoods, and school type, strongly limit equal access to bilingual education in Andalusia
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New microscopy method can help put sharper focus on plankton samples
description: A new method developed by EMBL scientists can help us identify and investigate plankton species in field samples with greater speed, accuracy, and resolution than ever possible before.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: An important step towards a novel method for early cancer diagnosis
description: Changes in the mechanical properties of cells are among the earliest signs of development of a cancer. Until now, one of the major obstacles to the use of mechanics in cancer diagnosis has been the lack of a standardized measurement procedure that would guarantee reproducibility and reliability of results. Thanks to European scientific cooperation involving the Institute of Nuclear Physics of the Polish Academy of Sciences in Cracow, this obstacle has now been removed.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Bewick's swans choose wintering areas based on the weather, shows long-term GPS data study
description: Bewick's swans fly less far during their autumn migration when the weather is warm. Climate change has therefore led to a shift in their common wintering areas. Now, for the first time, bird researchers from the University of Amsterdam (UvA) and the Netherlands Institute of Ecology (NIOO-KNAW) have been able to use long-term GPS data to pinpoint the specific choices that individual swans make. The results of their research were published today, Oct. 5,  in the journal Global Change Biology.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How much are you willing to pay for a product or service? It depends on your other options and the given context
description: Researchers from Concordia University and Northwestern University published a new Journal of Marketing study that presents the Comparative Method of Valuation as a more accurate way to measure customers' willingness to pay for a product or service.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Biologist improves carp growth with lactic acid
description: A RUDN University biologist and colleagues from Iran found that adding lactic acid to carp feed improves the growth and health of the fish. The authors selected the optimal concentration of the feed additive. It will help improve the quality of fish products. The results were published in the journal Animals.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study shows defects spreading through diamond faster than the speed of sound
description: Settling a half century of debate, researchers have discovered that tiny linear defects can propagate through a material faster than sound waves do.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Agronomists find microbes to protect tomatoes from dangerous fungus
description: RUDN University agronomists and colleagues from Tunisia have discovered a way to stop the spread of a phytopathogenic fungus Botrytis cinerea. It affects crops, especially tomatoes. The Trichoderma fungus and the Pseudomonas bacterium can protect the crop from this pathogen. The results have been published in the journal Agronomy.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New research shows plants could worsen air pollution on a warming planet
description: It's a simple question that sounds a little like a modest proposal: "Should we cut down all the oak trees?" asks Tom Sharkey, a University Distinguished Professor in the Plant Resilience Institute at Michigan State University.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Chemists make antibacterial films more effective with iron
description: RUDN University chemists have improved the effectiveness of antibacterial chitosan films used in medicine and the food industry, by adding iron and a new chitin derivative to chitin nanoparticles. The results were published in the journal BioTech.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Hubble finds bizarre explosion in unexpected place
description: A very rare, strange burst of extraordinarily bright light in the universe just got even stranger—thanks to the eagle-eye of the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope. The phenomenon, called a Luminous Fast Blue Optical Transient (LFBOT), flashed onto the scene where it wasn't expected to be found, far away from any host galaxy. Only Hubble could pinpoint its location. The Hubble results suggest astronomers know even less about these objects than previously thought by ruling out some possible theories.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Further evidence points to footprints in New Mexico being the oldest sign of humans in Americas
description: New research confirms that fossil human footprints in New Mexico are likely the oldest direct evidence of human presence in the Americas, a finding that upends what many archaeologists thought they knew about when our ancestors arrived in the New World.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers say that disinfectants can promote antibiotic resistance
description: According to figures published by the journal Nature, 73% of the world's antibiotics are used in the production of domestic animals. They are used primarily for preventive purposes because these animals are kept in confined and unhygienic conditions, but are also administered to promote growth.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Precise genome engineering and protein activity profiling uncover new cancer drug targets
description: Searching for new ways to block the growth of cancer cells is like looking for a needle in a haystack. Tumor cells rely on thousands of proteins to function, but only a few of those proteins can be precisely targeted by drugs to treat cancer safely and effectively. Now, a team at Scripps Research and the Broad Institute of Harvard and MIT has spearheaded a new method to home in on new drug targets most likely to impact multiple cancers.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Amazon rain forest hides thousands of records of ancient Indigenous communities under its canopy, says new study
description: The world's most diverse forest, the Amazon, may also host more than 10,000 records of pre-Columbian earthworks (constructed prior to the arrival of Europeans), according to a new study. The new study combines cutting-edge remote sensing technology with archaeological data and advanced statistical modeling to estimate how many earthworks may still be hidden beneath the canopy of the Amazon rainforest and in which locations these structures are most likely to be found.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Natural genetically modified crops: Grasses take evolutionary shortcut by borrowing genes from their neighbors
description: Grass may transfer genes from their neighbors in the same way genetically modified crops are made, a new study has revealed.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Chinese scientists are combating a glacier's melting by covering it with a blanket
description: One of China's most-visited glaciers in the Tibetan region, the Dagu Glacier, is now covered with white sheets, also known as geotextiles, in an attempt to slow its melting. Scientists at Nanjing University are leading the effort, and in July installed a white reflective material over 400 square meters of the glacier, located in Sichuan province in southwestern China.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Ozone hole grows large again
description: Measurements from the Copernicus Sentinel-5P satellite show that this year's ozone hole over Antarctica is one of the biggest on record. The hole, which is what scientists call an "ozone depleting area," reached a size of 26 million sq km on 16 September 2023. This is roughly three times the size of Brazil.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Big Earth imager to be tested on small Vega CubeSat
description: A briefcase-sized CubeSat being flown on Europe's next Vega launcher this week will gather 340 km wide views of Earth's vegetation growth, employing a spectral imager originally designed for ESA's decade-in-flight Proba-V.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Startup selection, success, and sustainability
description: In business, established companies are facing increasing pressure to embrace sustainability. To address this challenge, many incumbents are turning to corporate venturing, a process that involves collaborating with startups to tap into innovation and explore new markets.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A new qubit platform is created atom by atom
description: Researchers at the IBS Center for Quantum Nanoscience (QNS) at Ewha Womans University have accomplished a groundbreaking step forward in quantum information science. In partnership with teams from Japan, Spain, and the US, they created a novel electron-spin qubit platform, assembled atom-by-atom on a surface. This breakthrough was published in the journal Science.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Discovery made about Fischer–Tropsch process could help improve fuel production
description: A fundamental discovery about the Fischer–Tropsch process, a catalytic reaction used in industry to convert coal, natural gas or biomass to liquid fuels, could someday allow for more efficient fuel production.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New discovery may 'unlock' the future of infectious disease and cancer treatment
description: Researchers have identified a "guard mechanism" for a protein which attacks microbes in infected cells, opening the possibility of new treatments for toxoplasma, chlamydia, tuberculosis and even cancer.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers find a new quantum ruler to explore exotic matter
description: A single-atom-thick sheet of carbon known as graphene has remarkable properties on its own, but things can get even more interesting when you stack up multiple sheets.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The end of genes: Routine test reveals unique divergence in genetic code
description: Scientists testing a new method of sequencing single cells have unexpectedly changed our understanding of the rules of genetics.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Dragonfly eyes inspire new microlens array processing technique
description: Industry 4.0 requires simple solutions for complex functions. Optical sensors, such as pinhole cameras, can deliver a depth of focus and reasonable resolution, but they suffer from low intensity for reliable and fast imaging. This requires a long exposure time, which sacrifices fast imaging capability and limits their real-world usage in self-driving cars.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Queer characters in computer games: Greater diversity than before, but plenty of room for more
description: There have been queer players for as long as people have been playing computer games. But this has not been reflected in the characters that appear in the games.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study shows limestone can serve as a repository of microbial genetic information about the deep biosphere
description: Most of the Earth's microbial biomass is hidden in the subsurface. According to estimates, microorganisms can be found at depth of up to five kilometers below the continental surface. Here they also colonize solid rock. Since this deep biosphere is difficult to access, researchers know little about the composition and role of these microorganisms in biogeochemical cycles.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Climate change is a fiscal disaster for local governments: Study shows how it's testing communities in Florida
description: Climate change is affecting communities nationwide, but Florida often seems like ground zero. In September 2022, Hurricane Ian devastated southwest Florida, killing at least 156 people and causing an estimated US$113 billion in damages. Then Hurricane Idalia shut down the Florida Panhandle in September 2023, augmented by a blue supermoon that also increased tidal flooding in southeast Florida.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Q&A: Millions of US children have mediocre reading skills. Engaged parents and a committed school curriculum can help
description: Reading ability among U.S. students remained low in 2022, with 37% of fourth graders and 30% of eighth graders scoring below the basic proficiency levels for reading set by the National Assessment of Educational Progress.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Q&A: Johannesburg has been hit by severe water shortages—new plan to manage the crisis isn't the answer
description: Johannesburg and its surrounds, at the center of the industrial heartland of South Africa, have been hit by severe water cuts. Water interruptions have been happening for years, but they have been scaled up dramatically in recent weeks. The deteriorating situation recently forced the Minister of Water and Sanitation, Senzo Mchunu, to intervene. On 27 September he announced a new initiative—"water-shifting". The proposal has echoes of "load-shedding," the term used for the planned power outages which have become a common feature of life for all South Africans. Anja du Plessis, a water management expert, explains the new water initiative.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Made in America: How Biden's climate package is fueling the global drive to net zero
description: Just over a year since US President Joe Biden signed the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) into law, it's becoming clear this strangely named piece of legislation could have a powerful impact in spurring the global transition to net zero emissions by 2050.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How a disgruntled scientist looking to prove his food wasn't fresh discovered radioactive tracers and won a Nobel Prize
description: Each October, the Nobel Prizes celebrate a handful of groundbreaking scientific achievements. And while many of the awarded discoveries revolutionize the field of science, some originate in unconventional places. For George de Hevesy, the 1943 Nobel Laureate in chemistry who discovered radioactive tracers, that place was a boarding house cafeteria in Manchester, U.K., in 1911.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Foxes in Massachusetts caught and injured in illegal animal traps, police are investigating
description: Police are trying to find out who has been setting illegal animal traps, which recently caught and injured foxes in the Boston-area.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Digitizing UK natural history collections is vital to understand life on Earth, says report
description: A new report, published in Zenodo, has evaluated the use and impact of digitized natural science collections held in the UK and how they contribute to scientific, commercial and societal benefits.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: 6 things to know about NASA's asteroid-exploring Psyche mission
description: The first-ever mission to study a metal-rich asteroid, Psyche aims to help scientists learn more about the formation of rocky bodies in our solar system.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: $1B will bring more city trees, but it'll take more than seedlings to grow urban forests
description: Over the next five years, leaders in the Emerald City will spend millions in federal dollars to green up neighborhoods that lack trees. As Seattle and the surrounding region deal with more frequent extreme heat events, residents are starting to view trees as more than a luxury.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Gendered discrimination and disrespect 'all too common' in legal profession, Australian report shows
description: A new report, Designing Gender Equality into the Future of The Law examines the experience of women in the law including discrimination, harassment and overwork.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: In tune: Classical concert-goers' hearts, breathing synchronize
description: People who listen to music together often report feeling a powerful connection to each other as a result of their collective experience.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Laser-scribed graphene for sensors
description: With the development of the information era, sensors capable of transmitting and detecting information have become the leading way to obtain information. Therefore, building a sensor system with a wide detection range, high sensitivity and fast response is essential.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Lynxes and vultures offer insights for European wildlife conservation
description: EU research is providing the most far-reaching analysis of efforts to boost wild-cat populations and aiding scavengers that help balance the ecosystem.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Plot thickens in the hunt for a ninth planet
description: A pair of theoretical physicists are reporting that the same observations inspiring the hunt for a ninth planet might instead be evidence within the solar system of a modified law of gravity originally developed to understand the rotation of galaxies.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Cocoa prices are surging: West African countries should seize the moment to negotiate a better deal for farmers
description: The global price of cocoa is spiking, a direct response to dwindling cocoa output in west Africa. In September, cocoa futures reached a 44-year price peak due to mounting concerns over reduced supplies from the region.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Lion protection fee paid by tourists could help stop trophy hunting, says South African study
description: Trophy hunting is contentious. It typically involves paying for and pursuing a specific wild animal, often a large or iconic species, with the goal of killing it to obtain a trophy, such as the animal's head, horns, or hide.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Teachers can nurture students who care about the world: Four approaches that would help them
description: Teachers wear many hats. They are expected to be subject matter experts, leaders, administrators, managers, lifelong learners—and not just in the classroom, but in their wider communities.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How Europe's authoritarian populists maintain the illusion of a free press
description: Authoritarian leaders might be good at damaging democracy, but unless they are pure dictators they often still need to worry about winning elections. In the last few years, Europe has seen the rise of a number of authoritarian populists who rely on winning mass support among ordinary people—as opposed to just rigging the vote.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New study helps explain why people cooperate when no one is looking
description: That strong urge many people feel to abide by social norms even when it is individually harmful may have its roots in Darwinian fitness, according to a new study published in Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: In checking chess's gender bias, researchers find parents and mentors shortchange girls' potential
description: "The Queen's Gambit" miniseries portrayed the life of a fictional chess prodigy, Beth Harmon, who is continuously underestimated in male-dominated competitions. A team of New York University psychology researchers has now found some "real-life" evidence of what Harmon faced as a younger player: Parents and coaches of youth chess players peg the highest potential rating of girl players to be lower than that of boy players.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Hubble captures intermediate spiral galaxy NGC 6951
description: Bright blue spiral arms twist around the bright-white center of this starry galaxy. This new NASA Hubble Space Telescope image features NGC 6951, an intermediate spiral galaxy 78 million light-years away in the Cepheus constellation.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers propose radical change in how animal facial expressions are defined and studied
description: Researchers have developed a new method to analyze facial expressions, as part of efforts to better understand animal communication.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Gravitational distortion of time helps tell modified gravity apart from a dark force
description: With his theory of General Relativity in 1915, Albert Einstein revolutionized how we think about our universe. Rather than the cosmos simply providing the room for the planets and stars to orbit each other, space and time themselves were now dynamical entities in one ever-evolving play with matter and light.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Are we dating the same guy? Online groups toe the line between protecting women and defaming men
description: Infidelity and deception have always been part of dating and relationships. Traditionally managed privately between the parties or through legal processes, these issues have recently been co-opted by online vigilante communities that shame daters—men in particular—who behave badly.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Nobel Prize for chemistry recognizes the power of nanotechnology
description: The 2023 Nobel Prize for chemistry isn't the first Nobel awarded for research in nanotechnology. But it is perhaps the most colorful application of the technology to be associated with the accolade.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: It wasn't just a tree: Why it feels so bad to lose the iconic Sycamore Gap tree and others like it
description: The famous Sycamore Gap tree was felled last week, prompting global expressions of sorrow, anger and horror. For some, the reaction was puzzling. Wasn't it just a single tree in northern England? But for many, the tree felt profoundly important. Its loss felt like a form of grief.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Women take fewer risks because they think about losing more than men do, research suggests
description: One difference between men and women has been well documented by economists, psychologists and biologists—that women are tend to be more cautious and take fewer risks. Evidence has also been gathered about how this difference affects women's lives, particularly with regard to careers and earnings.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New path for early human migrations through a once-lush Arabia contradicts a single 'out of Africa' origin
description: Our species, Homo sapiens, migrated out of Africa multiple times—reaching the Levant and Arabia between 130,000 and 70,000 years ago, as exemplified by human fossils and archaeological sites found at various locations.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Yes, the original Barbie is a stereotype. But children also create their own 'Barbie worlds'
description: With the blockbuster success of the "Barbie" movie and the related expansion of Barbie branding and merchandising, educators and parents may find themselves wondering about Barbie's original purpose: as a child's toy.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Understanding the dynamics of snow cover in forests can help us predict flood risks
description: For more than six months a year, Quebec's boreal forest is covered in a thick blanket of snow. While this is essential for the balance of our ecosystems, for the people living downstream from forested watersheds the snow can be like a sword of Damocles hanging over their heads.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Chemists obtain derivatives of the natural polymer chitosan, which outpace existing antibiotics
description: RUDN University chemists and colleagues from Belarus obtained derivatives of the natural polymer chitosan, which exceeded existing antibiotics in antibacterial activity. Moreover, the new substances are non-toxic, and the production method is safe. The results were published in Polymers.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New research to improve production of high oleic sunflower oil
description: Researchers from Skoltech, Pustovoit All-Russian Research Institute of Oil Crops, OilGene—a startup launched in Skoltech—and other organizations have found new markers that will accelerate the breeding of high oleic sunflowers and improve the production of healthy oil with high oleic acid content. The study is published in PLOS ONE.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists unlock the secrets of a sixth basic flavor
description: Japanese scientist Kikunae Ikeda first proposed umami as a basic taste—in addition to sweet, sour, salty and bitter—in the early 1900s. About eight decades later, the scientific community officially agreed with him.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Feather-tailed possums in New Guinea were originally Aussies, according to fossil study
description: Analysis of Riversleigh fossils has revealed fascinating new facts about a tiny possum's ancestors. Scientists have long known that the miniature feather-tailed possums in Australia and the island of New Guinea—members of the marsupial family Acrobatidae—were evolutionary cousins, but where they started their long evolutionary journey has been a bit of a mystery—until now.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Old stars don't have hot Jupiters, suggests study
description: As we began to discover hundreds, then thousands of exoplanets, we found that there were two types of worlds unlike anything in our solar system. The first are super-Earths. These worlds straddle the line between large rocky worlds like Earth and small gas planets like Neptune. The second are hot Jupiters. Large gas giants that orbit their star in a matter of days.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: TikTok may help farmers cultivate empathy around climate change
description: Farmers are used to growing crops and producing other goods, but a new study led by Penn State researchers suggests the social media platform TikTok may help them cultivate something new: empathy around the issue of climate change.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientist adds cryo-ET and biosensors to fluorescence microscopy to image proteins within cells
description: Tinkerer though he is, Peter Dahlberg did not spend the last few years tearing apart a $1.5 million microscope just for fun.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Discovery may enable network interface for quantum computers
description: A team of scientists at the QOT Centre for Quantum Optical Technologies, including a student from the Faculty of Physics (University of Warsaw), made a device capable of the conversion of quantum information between microwave and optical photons.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Mukbang influencer marketing and consumer engagement with food brands
description: Ever find yourself inexplicably sucked into (another!) video of social media influencer downing a massive feast of 100 different kinds of shrimp? You can't scroll past. And before you know it, you're craving crustaceans, making reservations at that new seafood restaurant, and searching for recipes.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Little-known beaked whale found in cold waters off Hokkaido
description: Cetaceans are the best-known fully aquatic animals, including whales, dolphins and porpoises. The group includes more than 90 existing species, divided into baleen whales (Mysticeti) and toothed whales (Odontoceti). Toothed whales are so named because all species in this family possess teeth. Among them, the distribution and ecology of genus Mesoplodon are little known, because they typically live offshore in the ocean and rarely surface.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Climate intervention technologies may create winners and losers in world food supply
description: A technology being studied to curb climate change—one that could be put in place in one or two decades if work on the technology began now—would affect food productivity in parts of Earth in dramatically different ways, benefiting some areas, and adversely affecting others, according to projections prepared by a Rutgers-led team of scientists.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Fear of human 'super predator' pervades the South African savanna
description: Research published October 5 in the journal Current Biology finds that mammals living in South Africa's Greater Kruger National Park, home to one of the world's largest remaining lion populations, are far more afraid of hearing human voices than lion vocalizations or hunting sounds such as dogs barking or gunshots.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New research may make future design of nanotechnology safer with fewer side effects
description: A new study, published in Nature Nanotechnology, may offer a strategy that mitigates negative side effects associated with intravenous injection of nanoparticles commonly used in medicine.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists discover the highest energy gamma-rays ever from a pulsar
description: Scientists using the H.E.S.S. observatory in Namibia have detected the highest energy gamma rays ever from a dead star called a pulsar. The energy of these gamma rays clocked in at 20 tera-electronvolts, or about 10 trillion times the energy of visible light. This observation is hard to reconcile with the theory of the production of such pulsed gamma rays, as the international team reports in the journal Nature Astronomy.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Survival of the newest: The mammals that survive mass extinctions aren't as 'boring' as scientists thought
description: When an asteroid hit the Earth 66 million years ago, it set off a devastating mass extinction. The dinosaurs (except for a few birds) all died out, along with lots of the mammals. But some small mammals survived, laying the groundwork for all the mammals alive today.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The medicine of the future could be artificial life forms
description: Creating artificial life is a recurring theme in both science and popular literature, where it conjures images of creeping slime creatures with malevolent intentions, or super-cute designer pets. At the same time, the question arises: What role should artificial life play in our environment here on Earth, where all life forms are created by nature and have their own place and purpose?
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Nanoscale rust: The future of magnets?
description: Every motor we use needs a magnet. University of Manitoba researcher Rachel Nickel is studying how rust could make those magnets cheaper and easier to produce.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Novel organic-inorganic semiconductor generates circularly polarized light
description: A research team under the direction of Prof. Dr. Felix Deschler at Heidelberg University's Institute for Physical Chemistry has developed a semiconductor that efficiently generates light and simultaneously gives that light a certain spin. According to the researchers, the so-called chiral perovskite material has great technological potential that can be used for applications in optoelectronics, telecommunications, and information processing.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Successful morphing of inorganic perovskites without damaging their functional properties
description: A research team co-led by scholars from City University of Hong Kong (CityU) has successfully morphed all-inorganic perovskites at room temperature without compromising their functional properties. Their findings demonstrate the potential of this class of semiconductors for manufacturing next-generation deformable electronics and energy systems in the future.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Oldest evidence of human cannibalism as a funerary practice
description: The remains of human bones with cutmarks, breaks and human chewing marks found across northern Europe show that some human groups living around 15,000 years ago were eating their dead not out of necessity, but as part of their culture.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Renewable energy through photo-electrochemistry
description: Photo-electrochemistry (PEC) holds the potential to convert renewable energy such as solar light into useful green fuels. However, most known PEC materials suffer from instability issues, which are difficult to track and cause a decrease in their performance under continuous operation.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Non-native plants migrate north as climate change advances, study finds
description: As climate change progresses, the chance of southern plant species spreading to northern regions increases. In Europe and America, many of the alien plant species come from their own continent. They usually originate in warmer regions closer to the equator—a phenomenon that could be exacerbated by climate change.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists develop microplastics detection kit with AI technology
description: A research team led by Dr. Ho Sang Jung of the Department of Nano-Bio Convergence at the Korea Institute of Materials Science (KIMS), a research institute under the Ministry of Science and ICT, in collaboration with the KOTITI Testing & Research Institute, has developed the world's first technology to rapidly and highly sensitively detect microplastics (MPs), which can cause human and genetic toxicity through environmental pollution and the food chain.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New process 3D prints glass microstructures at low temperature with fast curing
description: Using ultraviolet light instead of extremely high temperatures, a team of Georgia Tech researchers has developed a new approach for 3D printing small glass lenses and other structures that would be useful for medical devices and research applications.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Using artificial intelligence, scientists develop self-driving microscopy technique
description: As anyone who has ever skimmed a book or magazine can tell you, sometimes you don't have to read every word to grasp the essence. Inspired by this notion, scientists are harnessing the power of artificial intelligence (AI) to enable a form of "speed reading" in microscopy. This could revolutionize the way researchers acquire data and allow them to preserve the integrity of precious samples.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Chemists create sensors to track potassium and sodium in cell organelles
description: Two studies by scientists at the University of Chicago have demonstrated a new way to look into the inner workings of cells—in particular, to track the flow of ions inside the many tiny organelles inside the cell.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers suggest paired black holes pulled by cosmic expansion could seem to be one entity
description: A small team of astrophysicists and mathematicians from the University of Southampton, the University of Cambridge and Institut de Ci'encies del Cosmos Universitat de Barcelona has proposed that certain pairings of black holes held apart by cosmic expansion could be mistaken for a single equal-mass black hole.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Model shows how Amazonian forest degradation and monsoon circulation are interlinked
description: A pair of concerned researchers, one a mathematician at the University of Norway, the other a climatologist at the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research, has developed a computer model that shows linkages between forest degradation in the Amazon River basin and monsoon circulation.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Indian astronomers investigate star-forming complex S193
description: Astronomers from the Physical Research Laboratory in Ahmedabad, India and elsewhere, have inspected a star-forming complex known as S193, using multiwavelength observational data. Results of the study, published Sept. 21 on the pre-print server arXiv, shed more light on the properties of this complex.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Mont Blanc shrinks by over two meters in two years
description: France's highest mountain, Mont Blanc, has shrunk by over two meters in height over the past two years, researchers said on Thursday, measuring the Alpine peak at 4,805.59 meters (15,766.4 feet).
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: UK government urged to tackle 'killer' XL bully dogs
description: The UK government is facing calls to crack down on the backyard breeders of XL bully dogs, and even to cull the breed, following a string of horrifying attacks.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Shining a light on tiny, solar-powered animals
description: Animals and plants need energy. Some animals get energy by eating other animals, and many plants harvest the energy in sunlight through photosynthesis. However, in the ocean, there exists a remarkable group of small, worm-like animals called acoels that do both; some acoels form relationships (symbiosis) with single-celled, photosynthetic microalgae.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Extreme emotions and emotionlessness of UK immigration system make migrants deportable and disposable
description: The UK's immigration system uses a combination of strong emotions combined with emotionlessness to cast migrants as simultaneously 'threatening, polluting and irrelevant'—creating a group of people who are, ultimately deportable and disposable, new research reveals.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New species of tiny wasp comes with mysterious, cloud-like structures at ends of antennae
description: Fossil researchers have discovered a novel genus and species of tiny wasp with a mysterious, bulbous structure at the end of each antenna.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: At least 10 dead, 102 missing in India glacial lake burst
description: Indian rescue teams searched on Thursday for 102 people missing after a devastating flash flood triggered by a high-altitude glacial lake burst killed at least 10, officials said.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Bumble bees drop to shake off Asian hornets
description: Bumble bees have a remarkably successful method for fighting off Asian hornets, new research shows.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Japan lifts a tsunami advisory issued after an earthquake hit near its outlying islands
description: Japan issued a tsunami advisory Thursday after a strong earthquake struck near its outlying islands in the Pacific Ocean, but lifted it about two hours later. No damage was reported.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: September sizzled to records and was so much warmer than average scientists call it 'mind-blowing'
description: After a summer of record-smashing heat, warming somehow got even worse in September as Earth set a new mark for how far above normal temperatures were, the European climate agency reported Thursday.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Typhoon Koinu injures 190 and brings record-breaking winds to Taiwan
description: Typhoon Koinu swept southern Taiwan on Thursday, injuring 190 people but causing no deaths as it brought pounding rain and record-breaking winds to the island, leading to school and office closures.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Rare US bison roundup rustles up hundreds to maintain health of the species
description: South Dakota cowboys and cowgirls rounded up a herd of more than 1,500 bison Friday as part of an annual effort to maintain the health of the species, which has rebounded from near-extinction.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New research into pangolin genomics may aid in conservation efforts
description: A new paper in Molecular Biology and Evolution provides, for the first time, a comprehensive set of genomic resources for pangolins (sometimes known as scaly anteaters) that researchers believe will be integral for protecting these threatened mammals.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
